dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON DUNCAN, staring off, lost in thought. Some SUITCASES and COOLERS flank him. It’s a little cramped. PULL BACK to reveal he’s sitting in that ill-conceived ba bench seat that faces out the rear of a vintage 1971 Buic Estate station wagon.

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: «+. Duncan? CLOSE ON REARVIEW MIRROR. TRENT RAMSEY (MAN’S VOICE) glan back at Duncan.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Duncan, are you sleeping? Clearly, Duncan wishes he was.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: No. DUNCAN'S POV of a SUV of TEENAGERS passing by. They gawk, flip him off.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Let me ask you something. Ona scale from one to ten, what do you think you are? Beat. No response.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Duncan? I’m asking you how you see yourself. On a scale from one to ten.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: What? You need to speak up, buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (louder) I don’t know. DUNCAN'S POV of a BILLBOARD on the opposite side of the highway. It reads, “Turn around! You missed it! Water Wiz Waterpark! Two miles back!”

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: What don’t you know? How you see yourself? You don’t have an opinion? Duncan doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m just curious. Pick any number on a scale...

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: A six.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: A six! Trent takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: I think you’re a three. Damn. Duncan definitely doesn’t know how to respond.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you know why I think you’re a three? Do you know what would make me say that? (beat) Duncan...?

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: You don’t know why? You have no idea?

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: You’ve got to speak up.  Duncan turns all the way around, making eye contact with Trent in the rearview mirror.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: (louder) No.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Well, from what I’ve observed, I can’t say I see you putting yourself out there, buddy. From this vantage point, Duncan surveys the landscape. In the back seat, comfortably stretched out, asleep, and listening to her iPod, is STEPH...

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Meeting kids your own age. And, from what your mom tells me, you seem content just to hang around her apartment. .-. And, riding shotgun, his mom, PAM. She’s asleep as we

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that a fair assessment? That you're happy to just... Not do anything? Because, see, that’s a “three” to me. Duncan glances back at Trent in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But, the good news is I can tell you that there’s going to be plenty of kids, and plenty of opportunities at the beach for you to take advantage of this summer. And, it’s a big summer for all of us, really. See if we can make this work... You and your Mom, me and Steph... All making it work together. As a family. (beat) So, what do you say? Let’s try to improve that score. Aim higher than a three? Duncan sits back down, facing out the back. Grabs his iPo

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That sound good? (beat) You up for that, buddy?  He puts his earphones in, as we... BEGIN MAIN TITLES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The station wagon, in all its glory. Mint condition. Strapped to the top, more BAGS. As for the rest of the ca on the highway, very much 2012. The station wagon pulls o the EXIT RAMP. Another BILLBOARD reads, “This is it! This the exit! Water Wizz Waterpark!”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The station wagon drives along the main street. A quaint beach town. Dated. TOURISTS/LOCALS, flood the sidewalks. The station wagon arrives at a... STOP SIGN. A CONVERTIBLE pulls up behind. The DRIVER is wearing classic Vaurnet sunglasses. Although retro, they work for him. The Driver looks right at Duncan, enjoying awkwardness. Duncan doesn’t know where else to look. The Driver nods, smiles. The station wagon continues straight as the convertible turns off to the left, screeching away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The station wagon pulls into the DRIVEWAY. Beach front. Prime real estate. The house, a very masculine vibe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trent unpacks. Duncan takes in his “home” for the summer. Pam steps up behind him, puts her hand on his shoulder. T is our first good view of Pam, wearing a stylish HEAD SCA In fact, her whole look is unique. Her own. Duncan and Pa notice the “name” of the house over the DOORWAY. “Riptide Suddenly, BETTY, pops out, a Greyhound cocktail in hand. house’s name: “Booze Cruizin’.”

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Yoohoo!

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Are you kidding? We just got here. Betty descends the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God! One more night of drinking alone and I was going to kill myself! (then, re: cocktail) Yes, I’m off the wagon again. Accept it and move on. (then, re: station wagon) Nice ride, Trent. Does the eight track still work?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: (smiling) What? This is exactly the car my dad used to drive us in.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Huh. Old and shitty.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: You know how much I paid for this? It’s in cherry condition.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: A car salesman with bad taste. Shocker. Betty turns to Pam, invading her space.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hi. I’m Betty. Hi,... Pam...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Trent’s probably already No, um... We were just... talked shit about me. It’s okay if he has. Has he? What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY PAM
dialogues.text: (off scarf) Oh, thank you... I’m loving this. I couldn't pull it off. My hair seems to hate me.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY PAM
dialogues.text: (to Trent) (giving up) I like her. ..+. Okay. Pam goes to pull a suitcase out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: What’s not to like? Pam catches Trent, ogling. Embarrassed, she looks at Bett

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, honey. Get it where you can. I'd be on my back after a line like that. Just then, we hear a SCREEN DOOR CLOSE. Betty looks up to find SUSANNA THOMPSON, her daughter, standing on their de She's quite cute. A very “mature beyond her years” look.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Susanna, Trent’s here. And this is his girlfriend, Pam. Say, “Hi.” Duncan, curious, peeks over the top of the car.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Hi. Beat. Susanna stays put. Betty waits for more.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Yeah, but don’t come down. (to Pam/Trent, sotto) Just stand there, brooding. (then, noticing Duncan) Oh. You’ve brought me a man. How thoughtful. Who is this in all his “awkward stage” glory? Duncan embarrassed, peers over the top of the station wag seeing if Susanna heard that. DUNCAN'S POV of Susanna going back inside. Pam puts her arm around Duncan, pulls him in.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: This is my son, Duncan. She brushes the hair out of his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Oh my God. I was going to name my youngest “Duncan,” but my ex- husband thought it was nerdy. So, we went with “Peter.” Which, personally, I think is worse. But, it fits my son, so... (then, to Duncan) Don’t worry, you wear the name well. Trent, where’s Steph?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we’ve been here all of two minutes, so probably changing for the beach.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (to Pam) She's just like me. Screw cancer. I want to be an even golden brown. Everywhere. Trent, Pam, and Duncan start lugging stuff inside. There’ plenty to grab, but Betty doesn’t notice.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, everybody's back this year. The Gales. The Hutchisons. The Campbells, sans Ben because of the trial. (then, to Pam) Insider trading. (then) The Smythes. Oh, and the Keegans, who I’m not talking to, but you can if you want, but just know that most of us aren’t. Pam passes the mailbox, glances at it. CLOSE ON mailbox. The side reads, “The Ramseys.”

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, do you think you will? Pam?

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Do I think I will, what?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Talk to the Keegans.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Oh, I don’t know. I don’t even know them.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Well, do if you want to, but know that I’m mad at them. I don’t even want to get into why. They called me a C-U-N-T. (then, excited) You're going to love it here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan sits on a bench. Betty plants herself on a stool a helps herself to a bag of POTATO CHIPS. Trent makes a Mou Gay and tonic. Pam, unfamiliar with the kitchen, attempts put away groceries. It’s a “trial by fire” project.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: So, how was your winter? Pam starts to respond, but...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Because our year was a challenge. My niece was raped in October...

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Oh my goodness...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I know. Not even food courts are safe. Oh, and well, Bob, that’s my ex-husband, finally came out of the closet. Not a shock. Let’s just say that, in bed, his favorite view was the back of my head. Now, my oldest, Charlie, is still into the drugs and psychedelic music. The drugs I get. But, come on, Gary Garcia’s dead! Let it go, already! Betty laughs. Pam glances at Trent, mouthing the word “Gary?” Trent waves it off.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Duncan) Don’t do drugs, Declan...

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: ++. Duncan...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (not hearing) «+. They’re just terrible. Oh, and Susanna. Well, you saw. She’s a walking mood. Going through an “I hate my mother phase.” Taking her father’s side, as usual. Steph enters, wearing the tiniest of tiny bikinis.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, Steph, sweetie, don’t you look great. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's exactly the kind of suit that got me pregnant the first time.

dialogues.speaker: STEPH
dialogues.text: That’s what I’m hoping for.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Hey,...

dialogues.speaker: STEPH
dialogues.text: (rolling her eyes) I'm kidding! Steph grabs a beer from the six-pack on the counter. Thro Pam glances at Trent, who seems oblivious. Pam takes her look to Betty, who commiserates.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I know. I can’t drink beer anymore, either. (then, grabbing her sides) Look at these muffin tops. Oh, and my youngest, Peter... He had surgery to fix his lazy eye. Now, it’s even worse. I try to get him to wear the eye patch, so people don’t feel uncomfortable. But, what are you going to do? Steph shoves a couple more beers into her beach bag.

dialogues.speaker: STEPH
dialogues.text: I’m outta here.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Oh, hey, take Duncan with you. Trent makes a point to look at Duncan, encouraging.

dialogues.speaker: STEPH
dialogues.text: Fuck that noise. I told you I’m not baby-sitting him all summer.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: You're taking Duncan with you, young lady. Duncan looks at his Mom. “Do I not get a say?”

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: (off Duncan) Go to the beach, sweetie. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: PAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'll have fun. We’re just going to be unpacking here.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: (suggestive, playful) Well,... Trent caresses Pam’s ass, pulls her in and kisses her. Sh placates, but is definitely blushing.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: That’s our cue, kids. (then) Oh. Now, I am still having our annual Fourth of July Clambake even though Bob’s not here this year. He’s probably sucking off our gardener right now. Okay well, let's have a fun summer! Betty exits, taking the potato chips with her. Duncan glances at his mom, hoping to be saved. But, she’s lost i Trent.

dialogues.speaker: STEPH
dialogues.text: «+. You coming or what? Steph leaves. Duncan shuffles out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steph strides along. Duncan, still in jeans and a T-shirt lags behind.

dialogues.speaker: STEPH
dialogues.text: Keep your distance. And, just don’t die. I don’t need that shit over my head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steph sits in the sand with her friends, KATY and LAURA. Susanna is there as well, reading. Although the same age Steph, Susanna has a maturity level that is leaps and bou beyond the rest of the girls. Steph’s boyfriend (or “summ friend”), CHAD, is playing football with some GUYS nearby Seated off to the side, Duncan.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh hey, just so you guys know, my house is out this year for partying.  11.

dialogues.speaker: STEPH/KATY
dialogues.text: What?! Are you kidding?/I’m hating you right now! I’m serious.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: My grandmother came up with us. So, my mom’s like, “This could be her last summer alive.” And I’m, like, “Yeah, well, I’m currently living, so...”

dialogues.speaker: KATY
dialogues.text: What a selfish bitch.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I know. This is, like, my summer.

dialogues.speaker: STEPH
dialogues.text: Well, we can absolutely party at my place. My dad only gets to see me, twice a year, so he totally just wants me to be happy.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: That’s exactly the type of parent I’m going to be.

dialogues.speaker: STEPH/KATY
dialogues.text: It just makes sense./I’m gonna do drugs with my kids.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh my God. I forgot. Willem broke up with Jessica.

dialogues.speaker: STEPH/KATY
dialogues.text: Are you serious?/Good. I don’t get her face.

dialogues.speaker: STEPH
dialogues.text: Susanna, you have to get on that this summer. Steph hops up.

dialogues.speaker: STEPH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calling off) Chad! ANGLE ON Chad, preoccupied with his friends.

dialogues.speaker: STEPH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Chad!  12.

dialogues.speaker: CHAD
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: STEPH
dialogues.text: I want to go in the water!

dialogues.speaker: CHAD
dialogues.text: Then, go! Steph just takes the moment in stride, brushes off. She notices Duncan staring at them.

dialogues.speaker: STEPH
dialogues.text: What are you staring at, perv? Steph walks off with Katy and Laura...

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Where is that kid from, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: STEPH
dialogues.text: Albany. He and his mom. They live in, like, a one bedroom apartment.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA/KATY
dialogues.text: Eww! /Tragic.

dialogues.speaker: STEPH
dialogues.text: (noticing) Uh, Susanna. We’re all swimming! Duncan watches Susanna reluctantly jump up, join them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan heads back toward the houses. From the opposite direction, Betty and her son, PETER. Clearly, Betty has transferred her cocktail to a Solo cup.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Duncan, we were just coming to find you. This is Peter.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Hey, Duncan.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Hey. Betty wasn’t kidding. Peter’s eye goes in every direction Duncan doesn’t know where to look.  13.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Oh, just stare at the bridge of his nose. That’s what I do.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Mom. Are you shitting me?

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Well, if you wore the patch, I wouldn't have to keep telling people that, would I?! Duncan, I was thinking that you and Peter should hang out this summer. Lord knows he brought enough of his Star Wars dolls. You could have fun with those.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: They're action figures! And they’re classics! (then, to Duncan) I’ve got a rare wookie and the C- 3P0 with detachable arms. They lose value if I take them out of the boxes, but we can still have awesome battles with them.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: He needs human contact. He’s having too many conversations with those dolls.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, I'm not!

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I’ve heard you, Peter! You called that “Baby Foot,” or whatever, your best friend.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (not worth the effort) Boba Fett...

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (ignoring, to Duncan) So, should we set up a time for you two to get together tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Uh, I should check with my mom. Duncan starts off.  10 11 12 14.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (calling after) Okay, well, don’t stand us up because we know where you live! (then, to Peter) See, I told you. Your eye makes people uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You're the worst parent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan enters. From upstairs, PLAYFUL LAUGHING. Pam and Trent are clearly fooling around. With that, Duncan turns right around, and heads back out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan is lying on top of the roof, eyes closed, listenin his iPod. Unfortunately, he’s listening to REO Speedwagon “Can't Fight This Feeling.” AND, he’s singing out loud. He opens his eyes to see... Susanna standing beside the car, watching. Clearly, she’s back from the beach. Duncan fumbles with the iPod, drops The earphones stay in, the console falls to the ground. Embarrassed, he looks over, only to see that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: «+. She’s heading into her house.

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Duncan comes down the stairs. Pam is setting the dining r table for dinner. Trent, making drinks at the BAR. With them, KIP and JOAN, Trent’s friends. “KYRIE,” by MR. MIST blares on the stereo. (We hope.) They’re all trying to si along, but clearly don’t know the words. Joan is dancing, occasionally tugging on Kip and Trent to join her. But, t no avail. The song gets to the CHORUS. This part, Trent, Kip, and even Pam know well. However,...

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: (singing the chorus) “Carry a laser down the road that I must travel. Carry a laser through the darkness of the night...”  15.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: aughing, shouting over laughing houting the music) Whoa, whoa. Are you singing, “Carry a laser?”

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: That’s what it is. Trent, Pam, and Kip laugh.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: Why would anyone in their right mind write a song called, “Carry A Laser?”

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: (laughing, shrugging) Because they love outer space. She goes back to singing and dancing. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: JOAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (noticing Duncan) Uh-oh. You just walked in at the wrong time, stranger. Before Duncan can even protest, Joan is coaxing him onto “dance floor.”

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: This is Duncan. My son. These are Trent’s friends, Kip and Joan.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: I’m the one not grinding up on you.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: (laughing) I’m not grinding up on him. (to Duncan) Come on, I can’t get anyone to dance with me. Duncan looks to Pam for rescuing.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: (smirking) Oh. I’11 make it worse. Pam joins in. Duncan halfheartedly gives in. A lot of awkward movement. At this point, everyone embraces the ly “Carry a laser.” Full on singing.  16. Save for Trent, who puts on a good face, but is clearly o the moment. Steph descends the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: STEPH
dialogues.text: I’m out of here.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Oh, wait. I made dinner.

dialogues.speaker: STEPH
dialogues.text: Oh, shoot. I have plans.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Steph, check out his moves. Steph watches for a short beat...

dialogues.speaker: STEPH
dialogues.text: Enjoy therapy. She grabs beers off the bar and goes.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Alright, we did that... Trent turns down the music. Duncan, self-conscious, stops dancing. Pam grabs a PLATTER of HOR D’OURVES and BOX OF CRACKERS, places them on the COFFEE TABLE.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, buddy, any chance you were on top of my car?

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: «+. No. Without even being prompted, Duncan helps Pam, opening th CRACKERS.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Cause there was a dent in the roof. It popped back up. So, it’s okay. I’m just wondering if you knew anything about that?

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: (innocent) Well, we did have bags up there, honey. Not the one he wanted to hear from, but...

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: That’s true. We did. Fair enough.  17. Trent smiles for Pam’s benefit.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pointed, to Duncan) So, that’s probably it. He winks at Duncan.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Can I help you with this, too, Pam?

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Oh. No. Thank you. (then, smiling at Duncan) We've kind of got a system. Trent puts his arm around, Pam.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: We've got a good team, here. He kisses her cheek. He seems proud. Duncan steps away, stops helping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Post dinner. Joan, holding court. Duncan pushes remnants food around on his plate.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: No, I can tell you exactly where I was. Passed out in the dunes. The guys laugh. Pam is out of the loop, but puts ona gracious face.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: That's right!

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Because, you left me there!

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: No, now wait! Kip wanted to go out on his boat. He said you’d be fine by the fire.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: You never came back!

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: (scoffing) The next day I did. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: KIP, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I poked you with a stick to wake you. It was real romantic. The guys laugh.

dialogues.speaker: PAM JOAN
dialogues.text: You know, I once went to this (to Trent) horrible luau-themed party... Now, was it last summer...?

dialogues.speaker: PAM JOAN
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m sorry... (faux sincere) No. Go. Please.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: No, please. You were talking...

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Tell your story, babe.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: Yeah. Enough of us, reminiscing...

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: It’s dumb...

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Well, now we have to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: (quickly) One time I went to this luau and passed out in the dunes, too. That's basically it. Dead air. A flop of a story. But, everyone feigns enjoyme to ease the awkwardness for Pam.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: (passively) .-. Oh, how funny.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: It was just... A similar thing to... Trent pulls in Pam close. He’s very attracted to this sid of her. Kip starts piling more food onto his plate.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: Okay, I just have to point out that I'm loading up for the third time. Pam, absolutely incredible.  19.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: No, thank you. (re: Trent) Sorry this asshole sprung us on you, last minute.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: It’s fine. I’ma caterer. I love cooking for people.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: You cater? That makes sense. Joan takes a sip of her wine, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: One of her many talents. Trent kisses her. Pam smiles, graciously. She’s not used being put on a pedestal. It shows.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She's also got some ideas for fixing up the place...

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: You mean,... (playing it up) +. the “Riptide?” Trent laughs, deflects. He takes a lot of shit for this.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: (clarifying) I mentioned rearranging a few things.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Hey. Put your stamp on it. I’m not set in my ways.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: (scoffing) Tell that to Christine. Kip lightly nudges Joan. A little awkward silence, then..

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: (moving on) Okay. I’m sorry, I have to put my son out of his misery. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: PAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Duncan) You're free to go. With that, Duncan jumps up from the table. Finally, relie

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: But, take your plate, buddy. We clean up after ourselves in this house. Duncan complies, as Trent pours Pam some more wine. She watches her son head off to the KITCHEN, as...

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Okay. My story now. Trent, was it last summer that you and I got stuck out on our boat?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: (pointing to Kip) Yes, cause this bastard buys gas, three dollars at a time! They all laugh, and continue to reminisce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan looks around aimlessly for anything to pass the ti - Surveys the BOOKCASES. Slim pickings. Mostly Louis L’Amour-type novels. - Checks out a PLAQUE. It’s engraved. “Trent Ramsey, Car Salesman of the Year.” - Looks at FRAMED PHOTOS. One catches his eye. A GROUP SHOT. Among them, Trent, Kip, Joan, and Betty. AND, there one WOMAN of interest. While everyone else is looking at CAMERA, she’s looking at Trent. But, she’s turned at such angle that we can’t see much of her face, if any at all. Hanging onto her, Steph, smiling at the CAMERA. - Opens a CABINET. Practically empty, save for one old, ratty edition of CANDYLAND and a 500 PIECE PUZZLE (Someth lame, like kittens in a basket.) INT. BEACH HOUSE - DUNCAN’S BEDROOM - LATER THAT NIGHT Al Duncan sits on the FLOOR. In front of him, the almost completed PUZZLE. Just two pieces left to put in. He look around. Shakes the box. No pieces to be found. Sighs and just starts taking it apart.  15 21.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan walks out, looks out over the dunes.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Susanna, close the screen door! I’m getting eaten alive by mosquitos! Duncan looks over at the adjacent deck, noticing Susanna, sitting in a lounge chair. She gets up, slams the screen door shut.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don’t like the way you’re acting, young lady! You wouldn’t be this way if your dad was here! Feeling Duncan’s stare, Susanna looks over. Caught, he lo away quickly. Beat. Checks back to see if... Yep. Susanna’s still looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: «.. Hey. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry about... I didn’t mean to...

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Oh, I don’t care. It’s not like we were using our inside voices.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: That’s cool. That’s cool. Beat. An eternity.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: So,... You’re a big fan of REO Speedwagon?

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: ... What?

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: “Can't Fight This Feeling?”  22.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Oh, no. My mom must have put that on there.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Oh, and you just got to it and thought, “What the hell. I’m going to sing the shit out of it, anyway?”

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: (trying to play it off) Something like that. We hear LOUD LAUGHTER from inside Trent’s house.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Sucks here, huh?

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: (shrugging) It’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: It sucks.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, no. Totally. Big time. Beat. Susanna waits for more, then...

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Alright, well... She starts back inside.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Feels like it’s going to be a hot summer.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Oh. I thought we were done.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Oh,... I was thinking about that earlier... That hot thing... And, it just came to me again.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Okay. Well, if something else comes to you,... Again. I’11 be inside.  16 17 18 19 23. Susanna heads in. Duncan collapses into a lounge chair, making himself as small as he can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is just coming over the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan enters. It’s a mess. Everything left out from the night before. Clearly, not everyone cleans up after themselves. Steph is there, scavenging the fridge.

dialogues.speaker: STEPH
dialogues.text: They drank all the beer. She slams the fridge door, storms out. Duncan finds a $20 BILL on the COUNTER. Next to it, a NOTE. It reads, “Up late. Sleeping in. Love you, Mom.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan walks down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Peter, don’t get mad at me. I don’t know where you’re looking! Duncan stops in his tracks. Shit. ANGLE ON Betty and Peter, at the base of their front STAI

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Forget it! It’s gone!

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Well, next time you say, “Look at the seagull,” you have to remember to point! Duncan quickly runs around the side of the STORAGE SHED, opens it. A BIKE leans against the back wall, but we can’ quite make it out.  20 21 22 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan rides the bike. A girl’s PINK CRUISER, complete wi front basket and tassels. But, he doesn’t care. For the first time, he seems content. EXT. MARC ANTHONY’S - DAY - LATER 21 It’s a PIZZA JOINT. A cool, old school vibe. Duncan leans the BIKE against the wall. Parked at the CURB, the Convertible we saw earlier. INT. MARC ANTHONY’S - DAY - MOMENTS LATER 22 Duncan is at the COUNTER, buying a SOFT DRINK. Behind him table of rowdy GUYS, all in BLUE SHIRTS, eating pizza. We hear the familiar MUSIC of a PAC MAN GAME starting. Dunca attention is drawn to the... BACK GAME ROOM. Another BLUE-SHIRTED GUY is playing Pac M EXCEPT for the classic PAC MAN upright, the rest of the v games are very 2012. Duncan approaches, standing right behind the Guy, watching.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Do you mind standing to the side? I’m getting your reflection in the screen.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: «+. Sorry. Duncan steps to the side. As he does, we get our first go look at the guy. It is, in fact, the DRIVER of the convertible. CLOSE ON LOGO. It reads, “Water Wizz.”

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t normally care, but I’m having the game of my life. I’m on the cherry level.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: But, that’s the first level.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Yeah, and I still have one man left. So, like I said, it’s the game of my life.  25.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: (smirks ) You like Pac Man?

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: What? It’s a classic! (re: other games) Not into all the bells and whistles, my man. Too much going on. CLOSE ON Pac Man screen. Pac Man chases a “blinking ghost barely devouring it before it changes back.

dialogues.speaker: GUY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See, my mistake is that I get greedy. Going for all the ghosts and fruit instead of just clearing pellets.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: You know, there’s a pattern.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: Oh, don’t tell me you’re one of those guys. That takes all the challenge out of it. Anybody can learn a pattern. Just then, the blue-shirted GUYS start to get up, putting their TRAYS.

dialogues.speaker: BLUE-SHIRTED GUY
dialogues.text: Owen, we gotta go! We hear the familiar sound of PAC MAN DYING.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN, (GUY)
dialogues.text: Well, so much for the game of my life.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: You still have another man left.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Naw, I’ve yet to see the second board. Gives me something to look forward to.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Oh, the board’s always the same.  23 26.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Well, there’s that. Thank you. Now, I can die. Here. You play it.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: No, I...

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Go, go. It’s all you. Duncan plays. OWEN (CONT’D) But, it’s still my quarter. So, if you end up getting a high score, I don’t want to see... What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: --- Duncan.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Okay, well, I don’t want to see that up on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Oh, they only let you use three letters.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Wow. Nothing’s left to the imagination with you, huh? Owen starts to walk away. OWEN (CONT’D) Oh and hey, no pattern on my quarter, man. Cut your own path. Duncan watches him leave. Suddenly, we hear PAC MAN DYING again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan pulls up on his bike. Pam and Trent are loading a large COOLER into the station wagon. Steph, leaning again the car, putting on suntan lotion.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: There you are. We were just about to leave without you. Where did you run off to?  24

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: (shrugging) Nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Well, let’s leave notes, okay?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Your mom was worried.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Now, go put on your swim trunks. Kip and Joan invited us out on their boat. And, we’re running late. Duncan heads toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Head’s up, buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON DUNCAN, catching a life vest. PULL BACK to see Duncan standing on the dock. the back, the boat’s name, “BARELY A WAKE.” the edge of the boat.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: You need to wear that.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: Oh, I think he’s cool without it.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: No, Duncan can’t swim.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: (trying to make it better, clarifying) Trent, he’s just not a comfortable swimmer.

dialogues.speaker: KIP
dialogues.text: I really think he’1ll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: No, let's wear it, buddy. So, people don’t have to worry about you, right? Everyone is loading stuff onto a large motor boat, all tricked out. Trent stands on 24 On  25 28.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yoo hoo! Betty walks down the dock, followed by Peter, who’s carry a BUCKET, and Susanna.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes, we invited ourselves. Accept it and move on. Peter has to stay down below. His eye throws off his equilibrium and he’1l get sick everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No, I won’t, mom!

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Tell that to the bucket we have to bring! Duncan, reluctantly, puts on the vest.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: (sotto, to Pam) Why do I have to wear this? No one else does.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: He just wants you to be safe. Susanna walks by, lifting an eyebrow, as Pam tightens the straps on his vest.

dialogues.speaker: PAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that snug enough? Off Duncan’s look...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON Duncan, sitting. He’s miserable. The life vest i three sizes too big for him. It comes halfway up his face The adults sit around the STERN of the boat. Steph and Susanna sunbathe on the BOW. CLOSE ON a beat up COOLER. Pam opens, revealing her “work Impeccable food. It outclasses the container for sure.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Basically, he was relentless. And, don’t get me wrong. I was looking. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had been divorced well over a year. It just...

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: It just took a little persistence on my end. Pam smiles, caresses Trent’s cheek. Pam sets out creating a spread on a table. Kip starts helping instantly to the annoyance of Joan.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Well, I wasn’t sure about you.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: I met her when she was catering some Halloween party in Albany...

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: (teasing) He went as a sexy cop.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: (laughing, defending) No, I was a 70s, bad ass cop.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: He followed me around all night, saying that he was there to “protect and serve” me. 29. her dishes, himself Trent, playfully, tries to put his hand over Pam’s mouth, she pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: PAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That about ended it right there for me.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (sotto, to adults) Sadly, I would have been working his bag by that point.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: (to Pam) Now, you did let me help you load up your van at the end of the night.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Yes, I did.  30.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: But, it still took three months to even get her to go out with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls Pam in.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Three months? I didn’t know you had that kind of stamina.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: She definitely made me work for it. But, it was worth it.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: There may be hope for you, yet.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: (to Pam) What finally changed your mind?

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: He told me that we were already in this together, so I might as well. It’s been almost a year now. They kiss. Joan finishes her wine. Trent, Kip, and Betty start to make plates for themselves. Pam notices Duncan, sulking. ANGLE ON DUNCAN. He glances over at Steph and Susanna. Steph catches him. She nudges Susanna, whispers. They bot laugh. Duncan fumes. Pam approaches.

dialogues.speaker: PAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (light, jokingly) Could you look a little more miserable?

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Could he be even more of a dick? Pam’s smile instantly fades.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Hey. He’s making an effort. Duncan looks away.

dialogues.speaker: PAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He wants this to work. He wants us to be a family.  26 27

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: He says that, but that’s not what he does.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Look, I know it’s not easy, but... You promised, remember? That you'd give it a try.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know why I can’t just go to dad’s for the summer. Pam puts on a good face, moving through...

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: .+. Because you’re with me. Duncan just looks off, checks out. He doesn’t “feel” like he’s with her. Eventually, Pam returns to the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is unloading. Trent is helping the women off the boat offering them a hand as they step down. Duncan jumps onto the dock, throws off his life preserver.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Hey, buddy, the cooler’s not going to get to the car by itself. Joan steps up to the side of the boat. It’s her turn to s down. Trent offers his hand. She makes a point to reject it, getting down on her own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan stands among the remnants of a “destroyed” table. Half-eaten rolls, corn cobs, opened bottles of wine. Clearly, the party had moved to the house. From OUTSIDE, we hear muffled LAUGHING/TALKING. Duncan lo out the WINDOW. The adults stumble along the dunes, singi loudly. Duncan sighs and starts to clean up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An establishing shot of the house from the DUNES.  28 29 30 31 32 32. INT. BEACH HOUSE - DUNCAN’S BEDROOM - SAME TIME 28 Duncan is awoken by the muffled sounds of ADULTS TALKING, LAUGHING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan descends the STAIRS. Pam, Trent, Kip, and Joan are eating breakfast. They’re still in their clothes from the night before. The table, a mess again.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: (noticing) Good morning, sweetie. Duncan gives her nothing.

dialogues.speaker: PAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you want any breakfast...?

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: (short) No. I’m good. Duncan walks off. Pam watches him leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan pulls out the pink cruiser. Standing on her FRONT STEPS next door, Susanna watches him leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan rides the bike, peddling furiously. He’s doesn’t k where he’s going. He just knows he wants to be somewhere else. Eventually, he stumbles upon... WATER WIZZ WATERPARK. TRACKING SHOT of Duncan riding up to the park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan enters through an open GATE. An EMPLOYEE enters behind him, carrying a BOX, shuts the gate door. Duncan already seems overwhelmed and out of place. CHILDREN run amok. TEENS congregate around the lounge chairs. EMPLOYEE congregate around the MAIN OFFICE.  33 33.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How'd we do? Duncan finds... Owen, standing on a SMALL DECK over the M OFFICE. He’s in a ratty BATHROBE, eating breakfast. OWEN (CONT’D) Nothing less than highest score I hope. I’ve got a reputation to protect. CAITLIN, a fellow coworker, emerges from the MAIN OFFICE below. Cute. No nonsense. Sardonic. She pretty much runs the place.

dialogues.speaker: CAITLIN
dialogues.text: (to Owen) Hey, whenever’s convenient for you, we are open for business.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: (to Duncan) See? I’m held in high regard. (then) Caitlin, I’m going on break. Caitlin rolls her eyes, heads back into the office. OWEN (CONT’D) See what I did?

dialogues.speaker: CAITLIN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah. It was clever as shit. As Owen goes into the apartment, Duncan finds an empty PI TABLE near the front entrance, sits. Dressed in jeans and T-shirt, Duncan should stand-out among the scantily clad patrons, but somehow he disappears. As he watches life in the waterpark continue around him, we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan, getting on his bike. Caitlin locks the GATE from inside. The last remaining GUESTS are walking to their ca Duncan watches as Owen heads into the apartment above the main office.  34 34. EXT. BETTY THOMPSON’S HOUSE/STREET (FRONT) - DAY - A LITT

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Duncan rides up.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Sweet ride. Duncan finds Susanna, on her front steps. In her hands, a CELLPHONE. Duncan seems to be holding onto a little resentment from the boat incident. He doesn’t even get of his bike. Just circles around and around in the street.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Oh, it’s not mine.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Yeah, I figured. Susanna walks down to the street, smiles. But, she can’t help but register Duncan’s aloofness. She tries another tactic. SUSANNA (CONT’D) You were right, by the way. It is a hot summer. Duncan stops, reluctantly smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I just call it like I see it.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: (holding up phone) I’m waiting for my Dad to call me back. I don’t want to be inside because my mom will just stare at me while I’m on the phone. She's all freaked out that I’m gonna want to live with him, or whatever. Duncan finally stops riding, connecting with Susanna.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: My mom’s the same way. Duncan rides toward the bike shed.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: So, let me know if you have any other observations on weather patterns.  35 36 37 35.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: (glancing back) Will do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan closes the door, starts around the corner...

dialogues.speaker: PAM, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'll see if he’s out front. Just as Pam opens the screen door, Duncan pops back again the shed wall. Pam checks her watch. Duncan waits until it’s safe, then sneaks off toward the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan sits at the edge, looking out onto the beach/ocean He turns, looks back at the house. One last UPSTAIRS LIGH goes OFF.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan starts up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I thought we had a deal about leaving notes. Checking in. Duncan jumps, slightly startled. ANGLE ON Trent, sitting in a chair, eating a sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: My mom and I do.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: You worried her. Again. I told her I'd wait up for you.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Well. I’m here. He starts up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Hey, Duncan? Duncan stops. Beat.  36.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not interested in talking to the back of your head, so... Duncan turns around, full of 14 year old attitude.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If we’re going to make this work, and it is “we,” then there needs to be trust. And, respect. Am I right? I think that’s something we both want.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: -.. Fine.

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: There you go, buddy. Duncan turns, and heads upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan is back on the edge of the same PICNIC TABLE, stil sporting the jeans and T-shirt look.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I’m going to have to ask you to leave. Duncan looks back over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: -.. What?

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, you're going to have to take off. I’m getting complaints. You're having too much fun. It’s making everyone uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Oh. ... Okay. Duncan actually gets up, starts out. Owen is genuinely thrown by Duncan’s reaction... Stifles a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Whoa. Wait... (laughs ) I’m sorry. I shouldn’t be... I didn’t think you would actually...  39 37. Duncan’s not sure what’s going on. Owen gathers himself. found that very endearing and funny. OWEN (CONT’D) (gesturing him to follow) Come on... Duncan seems reticent. More confused, really. OWEN (CONT’D) Look, I can tell you’re in complete awe of that picnic table. It is one-of-a-kind except for the 200 exactly like it around here. But, there is more park to be seen. Finally, Duncan complies, follows. OWEN (CONT’D) First things first. As much as I’m a fan of Tuff Skins, we’ve got to get you a swimsuit. Seriously, when’s the last time you bought jeans?

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Oh, my mom buys my jeans...

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Good. Always take things literally. How’s that working out for you? You getting laid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Owen and Duncan approach LEWIS, working behind the counte He’s quite a curmudgeon, pale as can be, and his Water Wi employee shirt is WAY too big for him.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Lewis, hook up my man, Duncan, here with one of our finest rentals.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: Some kid threw up near Crazy Tubes.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Whoa, let’s try not to impress him all at once.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: That will not be a challenge.  38.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Lewis is kind of over this place.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: I told you. I’m not long for here.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: No, I remember that conversation. In 2003, 5, 11, April, two days ago...

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: I’ve just got things I want to do.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Prove it. Without thinking, rattle off three. Go. Owen smiles at Duncan. He loves goading Lewis.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (complying) I don’t know. See New Mexico. Take Invent something. Become a storm chaser...

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: You had me until number three. I think you have to go to school for that.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: (scoffing) “Hey, look. There’s a storm.” “Where?” “Over there.” “Cool. Let’s go get it.” “Got it.”

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Wait. Are you chasing them or capturing...? Lewis waves him off, pulls out a pair of ragged-looking s trunks from below the counter, hands them to Duncan.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: These don’t have any mesh, so you're basically going “commando.” Watch sitting. You’re junk will fall out.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: And like that, you're impressed. And, grossed out.  40 39. Off Duncan,... EXT. WATERPARK - BUZZARD’S BAY GIFT SHOP - MOMENTS LATER

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: We STEADY CAM as Owen leads Duncan, now wearing the ill- fitting swim suit, on a “tour of the park.” This is our first real glimpse of Water Wizz in all its glory. Clearl built in the 80’s and from the looks of it, hasn’t change bit.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Water Wizz Waterpark. Built in the summer of ‘83, it’s the last bastion of everything that time period stood for. In fact, it was decreed by its creator that this place shall never age. On his death bed, he said “I don’t want this place re-painted or updated. I don’t even want it brought up to code. And the minute someone tries, it needs to be destroyed.” Duncan doesn’t even bat an eye to this. Owen takes that i OWEN (CONT’D) We actually have a nuclear bomb for just such an occasion. Duncan still doesn’t get the joke. OWEN (CONT’D) Bought it off the Russians. Still nothing. OWEN (CONT’D) Really? Still good with all that? Even the Russian thing? That’s Cold War. Kind of dated. Duncan’s still blank. OWEN (CONT’D) Okay. Well, that was a waste of a bit. Caitlin joins them, clipboard in hand.

dialogues.speaker: CAITLIN
dialogues.text: Some kid threw up near Crazy Tubes.  40.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: (faux pissed) Why is this the first I’m hearing about this?! Dammit. (then, introducing) Caitlin, Duncan. Tony, Mary Beth.

dialogues.speaker: CAITLIN
dialogues.text: Hi, Duncan. (then) Also, I need you to reorder more T- shirts...

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Did it.

dialogues.speaker: CAITLIN
dialogues.text: Finish the work schedule for next week...

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Did it.

dialogues.speaker: CAITLIN
dialogues.text: Change all of the filters...

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Done.

dialogues.speaker: CAITLIN
dialogues.text: You know, I’m going to check.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Oh. Then, in that case, I didn’t do any of that.

dialogues.speaker: CAITLIN
dialogues.text: (slightly bemused) So, I’m doing it. Caitlin peels back the way she came.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: (calling off) It’s called delegation. I read about it in a book about it. Our STEADY CAM SWINGS around as Owen and Duncan turn... OWEN/DUNCAN POV of Caitlin walking away.
OWEN (CONT’D) (to Duncan) That’s the one you wait for, my man. He takes a moment, then we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN DOWN from SIGN. “DEVIL'S PEAK.” Owen and Duncan appro the entrance. Clearly, the main attraction. There’s a lon line.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: This is Devil’s Peak. The longest waterslide in a 50 mile radius. Stretch out the tube, end to end. 13 football fields. We STEADY CAM as they continue up the RAMP. OWEN (CONT’D) Don’t Google that for confirmation. That fact predates technology. Three boys, KYLE, NEIL, and JASON, run up. The nerds of t waterpark, but they don’t see themselves as that. They al make their way up the RAMP, past the long line of SLIDERS

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Owen, settle a debate for us.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Hello, boys. Duncan, this is Vladimir, Ismael, and Ming Lee.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Those aren’t our names!

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Those are the names I’m giving you, Vilady. (to Duncan) These are my illegitimate sons. All different mothers, but I want to make sure I’m a positive influence in their lives.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Shut up, jackass!  42. We CUT to a CAMERA on a SCISSOR LIFT as Owen and the rest continue up the STAIRS. We CUT to LANDING.

dialogues.speaker: JASON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Neil says that years ago some kid figured out how to pass someone on the water slide. Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: He did!

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: It’s physically impossible, Neil! You can’t catch up to someone and pass them!

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Actually, Ming Lee’s right. I was here when it happened.

dialogues.speaker: JASON
dialogues.text: Then how'd he do it.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: It happened inside the tube. So, no one knows. Only the kid and the person he passed,... And, well, Jesus. But, he’s hard to get a hold of.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Be serious!

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Don’t interrupt him, Neil! He was talking! STEADY CAM as they climb some stairs onto a SMALL

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Guys, what happens in the tube, stays in the tube. That’s just the law of the park.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Bullshit. We’1ll just ask the kid how he did it.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Be my guest. If you can find him. Last I heard, he went into a deep depression. The fame was too much. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: OWEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He turned to cocaine to escape the limelight. And eventually, to a life of male prostitution. Owen stops on the landing. OWEN (CONT’D) Oh, no. Wait. There he is. Owen points at a VERY YOUNG KID. Couldn’t be more than 8.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Screw you, Owen!

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Yeah, screw you, Owen.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: I just said that, Neil!

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: I'm being supportive! The boys head back down the stairs. Owen looks at Duncan, dead serious.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Actually, that crack-addled male whore... was me.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: ... Really?

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Wow. Do you get comedy? 4l EXT. WATERPARK - DEVIL’S PEAK - DAY 41 Owen and Duncan ascend the last of the stairs to the TOP LANDING.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: So, did he pass by sliding up the side of the tube?

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: (teasing) I’m not telling you.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: But, I want to know!

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: That’s a good thing. Don’t die wondering. A lifeguard, RODDY (BLUE-SHIRTED GUY from the pizza parlo is sitting at the mouth of the slide, pacing out the SLID OWEN (CONT’D) How’s it going, Hot Rod?

dialogues.speaker: RODDY
dialogues.text: Some kid threw up near Crazy Tubes.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Damn, pointless news travels fast.

dialogues.speaker: RODDY
dialogues.text: (to next Slider) Hold on. Alright, go. The Slider heads down. Another SLIDER steps up.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Can I get a special ride “with benefits” for my man, Duncan, here?

dialogues.speaker: RODDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, hold on. (then, to Slider) Alright go. A BEAUTIFUL WOMAN steps up.

dialogues.speaker: RODDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hold on. RODDY just stares at her butt for way too long.

dialogues.speaker: RODDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hold on. Hold. Hold. Hold. Hold. Alright... Hold. Hold. And, we're... Holding. Hold. Hold. Roddy milks this for everything it’s worth.

dialogues.speaker: RODDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (finally, to Woman) Alright, go. She goes.

dialogues.speaker: RODDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, Owen, go!  42 43 45. Owen pushes Duncan down the tube. He immediately follows. EXT. WATERPARK - BOTTOM OF DEVIL’S PEAK - DAY - MOMENTS L The three come shooting out of the tube into the water. Owen, acting clumsy, pretends to be all tangled with the Beautiful Woman.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Oh, excuse me. I’m sorry. Let me just... I can’t seem to get my footing. By now, the Beautiful Woman can’t help but smile. It’s th power of Owen.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUTIFUL WOMAN
dialogues.text: (laughing) Owen, come on!

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: It’s not me! It’s the punk kid. He’s like an octopus! Just then, a pair of ratty, old swim trunks pop up to the surface of the water. OWEN (CONT’D) And, uh... Looks like you lost something. Duncan realizes his swimsuit came off. He grabs them and puts them on. OWEN (CONT’D) (smiling) Oh. Too far, Duncan. You just had to take it too far. Duncan is beet red. OWEN (CONT’D) Can he get your number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan unlocks his bike. Owen pulls up in his convertible

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: You want a ride?  46.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: No, thanks. I’ve got my bike.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Where are you staying?

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Over by the beach, on Hampton.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: That's far. And, people drive like idiots on the Fourth. Throw your bike in the back.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Oh, no. You don’t have to...

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: No, it’s too much trouble....

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Duncan, we've got to start having faster conversations. Put it in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drive across. There are a few LOCALS carrying COOLER and BEACH CHAIRS along the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: So, what brought you to the waterpark? Not many kids head our way when the ocean’s their backyard.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know... I guess... There’s not much for me at home. (then, changing subject) How long have you been working there?  45 46

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: The park? I’ve always been there. 47. Owen watches as Duncan closes his eyes, enjoying the late afternoon sun on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 45 Duncan gets his bike out of the back. We can see that Betty’s Fourth of July Clam Bake is in full swing. PARTYGOERS are arriving, carrying lawn chairs and plates food around to the back. Her house is covered with decorations, to the point of being garish.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Thanks for the ride. Duncan walks the bike up the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Hey, I was thinking. I could use someone to be a floater at the park. Do odd jobs. If you’re interested... Duncan’s face lights up.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: (too much) Definitely. Awesome. Yeah. (then, collecting himself) No, totally. If you need me, sure. I mean, I could help out...

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Duncan.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: There you go. Tomorrow. 9AM. With that, Owen drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan runs up the stairs, just as Pam is exiting, platter of food. It’s heavy.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Who was that with you? 46 carrying a  48.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Just a friend.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: A friend who drives?

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Mom.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: What’s his name?

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Owen.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: And, how do you know him?

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Mom, he’s just a friend.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: (suspicious) A friend with a license? Well, you should bring him by. I’d like to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Fine. He tries to run past.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Whoa. I’m not done. Duncan stops, turns.

dialogues.speaker: PAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And, we don’t stay out all night and disappear all day. Do you understand me?

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: (under his breath) I could say the same to you.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: -.. What? Duncan leaves.  47 49.

dialogues.speaker: PAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (calling off) I want you to make an appearance at Betty's.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: I’m serious.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay. EXT. BETTY THOMPSON’S HOUSE - DAY - LATE AFTERNOON 47 CLOSE ON a DUG OUT SAND PIT, filled with COAL EMBERS and SEAWEED. Beside it, a large POT of CLAMS. We STEADY CAM a a PARTYGOER picks it up. With him, Betty, cocktail in han

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: Pretty impressive, huh, Frank? Those are all my doing this year. The Partygoer carries it onto BETTY’S BACK DECK, as the Camera follows her into TRENT’S BACKYARD. Betty looks up the DECK of the adjacent house. A COUPLE is sitting there excluded.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Happy 4th, Keegans! So sorry. The party’s filled to capacity! Betty joins Pam, Trent, Kip and Joan at a table as Duncan descends the BACK STAIRS, taking in the party. More PARTYGOERS mingle. Music blares. People are dancing, including CHARLIE (18), a very strung out looking hippie. He’s dangerously close to the fire, lost in his own world Steph and her “gang” of friends, including Chad, Katy and Laura, are huddled around a picnic table.

dialogues.speaker: STEPH
dialogues.text: Susanna! Duncan notices Susanna on her deck.

dialogues.speaker: STEPH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're hanging over here. Grab a cup, we’re playing quarters! Steph notices Duncan, makes a point to lay across the res the bench, excluding him.  50.

dialogues.speaker: STEPH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come sit next to Willem. He’s being hilarious. Duncan looks over at Betty, Pam, Trent, Kip, and Joan. ANGLE ON ADULTS.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: I think my first hint was catching Bob coiling our gardener’s hose. Then, there was our pool boy. Third strike, was Peter’s principal. Everyone gasps with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (nodding her head) P.T.A. meeting. You can imagine how that conversation went. “I’m concerned about safety in our school. Violence is on the rise.” “That’s not all that’s on the rise.” Betty imitates “porn music.” They all laugh.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (getting up, re: glass) This is empty. And, that’s just not right. (then, noticing) Oh, hey, Duncan. Pam looks back, reaches out for Duncan’s hand. He complie She pulls him closer.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You should hang out with Peter. He’s playing under one of these tables. (calling off) Peter!

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What?! Peter’s voice, in fact, comes from under one of the table clothed folding tables.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: There you go.  51. As Betty walks off....

dialogues.speaker: BETTY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (noticing) Charlie, don’t do your dead dance so close to the fire!

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Do you want me to make you a plate of food?

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: No, I can do it.

dialogues.speaker: BETTY
dialogues.text: (walking off) Be sure to get some clams. They were all my doing this year.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Bring your food over here and eat with me, okay?

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: (smiles) Okay. 48 EXT. BETTY THOMPSON’S HOUSE - DAY - CONTINUOUS 48 Duncan approaches the folding table, starts to make a pla

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: What’s up, Peter?

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey, man.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: How’s the battle going?

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Luke and Leia are hooking up.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: You know, they’re brother and sister, right?

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Cool.  52. Susanna approaches.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: I'd avoid the clams, if I were you. They're one of the many casualties of my father’s absence.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: ++. Oh. Duncan considers, but then puts a few clams on his plate.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (shrugging, to Susanna) Just because your mom’s going to see my plate.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: It’s your funeral. CHEERING. Duncan and Susanna look over by the fire. Charl is clearly enticing the adults with a large bag of pot. SUSANNA (CONT’D) Looks like my brother just made another sale. The adults head off, except for Pam. Trent takes her hand pull her up. She glances over in Duncan’s direction. Clearly, torn.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: «+. We'll be right back. And with that, she’s gone. Duncan dumps his whole plate o food into the garbage can. Susanna clocks. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Peter, do you want to go chase ghost crabs?

dialogues.speaker: PETER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hell, yes! Peter comes out from under the table.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Duncan? Any interest?

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: (coming to) Huh?  49 50

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Want to do something really lame?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: It’s not lame.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: (beat) Yeah. Sure.
49 Susanna and Duncan are walking. He seems lost in thought. In the distance, Peter, carrying a flashlight, is looking ghost crabs.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: When I was younger, my dad used to bring me down here to do this all the time. He’d fill my head with all these useless facts about ghost crabs. Like, did you know they’re omnivorous? Basically, they feed on both animals and vegetables. (then) My mom jokes, “Leave it to your dad to be interested in a creature that goes both ways.” Duncan can’t help but smile. Beat. SUSANNA (CONT’D) So, do you want me to keep talking, or are you going to say something eventually?

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: My mom doesn’t smoke pot. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Well, that’s the power of this place. It’s like spring break for adults. They smile, connect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50 Duncan and Susanna sit at the top, watching the fireworks explode over the ocean.  54.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: That’s what I think really kills my mom. Not that he left, but that he’s got someone and she doesn’t. Duncan nods. SUSANNA (CONT’D) Is your dad seeing anybody?

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, she’s a lot younger.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Classic.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: They're just getting situated in San Diego. You know? New place. So, he says it’s not a great time right now. But,... I’m going to visit him when he gets settled and stuff. It’s supposed to be awesome out there.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: California. That’s cool.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Beat. Duncan just looks out at the water. Susanna watches him. Just then, Peter runs by, chasing a crab.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Susanna, look! The crab grabbed the light saber! He’s got Luke’s light saber! This is the battle of all battles!

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: (to Duncan) How are you only a year older than him? EXT. BETTY THOMPSON’S HOUSE - DUNES - THAT NIGHT - A LITT

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Susanna and Duncan walk up the DUNES. Peter runs by, his arms outstretched as if he’s flying.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: So, where is it you go?  55.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Go where?

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: On your sexy, pink cruiser?

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Oh. Nowhere. Susanna smiles.

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: Oh. I see...

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: No, I just...

dialogues.speaker: SUSANNA
dialogues.text: It's okay. Let it be yours. She smiles. They approach... BETTY’S BACK DECK. Duncan glances over at the DUNES behind TRENT’S HOUSE. DUNCAN'S POV of Pam, Betty, and a group of women still sitting around the fire. They are all clearly high, drunk all of it. Susanna watches Duncan watch his mom. SUSANNA (CONT’D) «++ Good night.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: (coming to) Yeah, good night. Susanna head up the stairs. Duncan continues into Trent’s YARD. Suddenly, MUFFLED ARGUING from the side of the hous draws his attention to... «+. the side of TRENT’S HOUSE. Duncan peeks around. Joan, clearly drunk, is leaning into Trent. She runs her hand u his stomach and chest. Trent removes her hand, but she le in, kisses him. Although Trent doesn’t “kiss back,” he doesn’t pull away immediately. Thinking better of it, he finally turns his head away.

dialogues.speaker: JOAN
dialogues.text: Oh, I see. Just not this summer.  52 56. Pissed, she waves him off. Trent starts walking toward Duncan, who throws himself against the side of the house. Trent walks by, not seeing him. In his hand, a bag of MARSHMALLOWS. Trent approaches Pam and the rest.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: You were gone that long and you only brought the marshmallows?

dialogues.speaker: TRENT
dialogues.text: Joan has the rest. Trent joins Kip and Charlie who are clearly smoking pot. Duncan watches as Pam looks over her shoulder in the direction of where Trent came from, just as Joan is round the corner, fixing her hair. Joan joins them at the fire, handing a box of GRAHAM CRACKERS and CHOCOLATE BARS to Pa without even looking at her. Pam glances over, noticing Duncan. She takes a moment, then...

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: (to Group, upbeat) Who wants a S’more? Duncan just shakes his head, and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan rounds the corner of the booth, a little out of so from the night before. But, at least he’s in his OWN swimsuit. Owen is there with Lewis.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: You're late! Duncan looks like a deer in headlights. OWEN (CONT’D) Are you planning on making this a habit? If so, we’re done here. You know what? I’m tired of your sass. You're fired.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: But,... I just...

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: You make a valid point. Welcome back. With benefits.

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS
dialogues.text: You waste an exorbitant amount of time.  53 57.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Suit up. Owen throws him a blue shirt. Duncan doesn’t emote much excitement. OWEN (CONT’D) Come on, get pumped! This is a place where dreams are made. Or, destroyed. Depends on how you feel about working at a waterpark. Duncan puts the blue shirt on over his T-shirt. Caitlin approaches.

dialogues.speaker: CAITLIN
dialogues.text: Um, we have a situation over at Harpoon Lagoon.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: (dead serious) Is it a homicide?

dialogues.speaker: CAITLIN
dialogues.text: (dry) Yes. It’s a homicide. That’s why I’m so calm. Owen starts off...

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: (dramatic whisper) I knew this day would come. Caitlin and Duncan follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small crowd of waterpark PATRONS have circled up, watch some BREAKDANCERS going to town on a large piece of CARDBOARD. HIP-HOP BLARING from a BOOM BOX. (NOTE: Our “Breakdancers” are just TEENS who were at the waterpark. a “crew.” They would be dressed for the waterpark.) ANGLE ON SNACK SHACK. Roddy and a few other EMPLOYEES are watching. Owen, Caitlin, and Duncan approach, joining.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: (disappointed) Oh. There’s no blood.  58.

dialogues.speaker: RODDY
dialogues.text: (very matter-of-fact) They grabbed some cardboard from the snack shack and just started going to town. Mostly b-boying. Power, Abstract, Blowup, Flavor... Mad moves though. Applejacks, Coindrops, Turtles, Jackhammers, 1990s...

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Any Jookin? Buckin?

dialogues.speaker: RODDY
dialogues.text: (scoffing) Not this far from Memphis...

dialogues.speaker: CAITLIN
dialogues.text: (over it) Someone needs to take away their cardboard. It’s getting too congested.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: (to Duncan) You heard the lady.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: (taken aback) --- Oh, I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: CAITLIN
dialogues.text: No. Owen. You need to do this.

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: Naw, he’s got it. Duncan looks over, nervous. DUNCAN'S POV of the BREAKDANCING CIRCLE. A BREAKDANCING G moves center stage, holding court. He’s quite an imposing fellow.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: (meek) But,... It’s my first day...

dialogues.speaker: OWEN
dialogues.text: (off shirt) Hey. You're official now. You got this. Duncan takes a deep breath, walks off...  59. OWEN (CONT’D) (off Caitlin’s glare) I’m right here. I’11 step in. ANGLE ON Duncan, slowly approaching. He stops just outsid the circle, looks back at Owen, who gives him a thumbs up

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: (soft) .-- Excuse me. No one hears him over the music. They’re lost in their da circle.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey, uh, guys...? Nothing. Duncan shuffles over to the boom box, turns it o A smattering of disappointment from the Patrons. “Boo.”

dialogues.speaker: BREAKDANCERS
dialogues.text: Hey!/What the hell?! They all turn and look right at Duncan.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: I’m gonna... need to take your cardboard.

dialogues.speaker: BREAKDANCING GUY
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa. Our imposing fellow steps forward. Duncan’s eyes only com up to his chest. BREAKDANCING GUY (CONT’D) What, now?

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Um,.. I was told to take your cardboard. The Breakdancing Guy takes a moment, but eventually steps the side. Duncan makes his way through the very intimidat crowd. He reaches down, grabs the edge of the cardboard. foot SLAMS down onto it. It’s Breakdancing Guy, again.

dialogues.speaker: BREAKDANCING GUY
dialogues.text: Show us your moves. Duncan looks at him, confused.  60. BREAKDANCING GUY (CONT’D) Show us your moves. Then, you can take it.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Oh,... I don’t... I can’t, um, crunk or any of that.

dialogues.speaker: BREAKDANCING GUY
dialogues.text: Then, you can’t take the cardboard. He takes a moment, then starts to “pop ‘n lock” horribly. It's awkward, and jerky. This moment seems to go on for a eternity. Finally, he stops. No one reacts. They all just stare at him, blankly. Beat. BREAKDANCING GUY (CONT’D) (nodding head) Okay. Okay. He seems to be signing off. Duncan, relieved, goes to retrieve the cardboard.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Whoa. We’re not done. ANGLE ON a BEAUTIFUL BREAKDANCER emerging from the crowd. She turns the BOOM BOX back on. Grabs Duncan’s hand, lead him to the center of the cardboard.

dialogues.speaker: BEAUTIFUL BREAKDANCER
dialogues.text: Just mirror me. The Beautiful Breakdancer does a move, throws it to Dunca He tries to replicate it. Terrible. More moves. More mirroring. More butchering. The Patrons start to get into it.

dialogues.speaker: BREAKDANCING GUY
dialogues.text: Spin on your head! Just then, two big BREAKDANCERS pick Duncan up from behin flip him over. Duncan is now in a headstand. The Breakdancers start manually spinning Duncan by his legs, faster and faster, handing him off like a Tetherball. CLOSE ON Duncan's face, beaming. DUNCAN'S POV as he spins around and around. Suddenly, the guys let go. Duncan tumbles to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: BREAKDANCERS
dialogues.text: Stick it! Stick it!  54 55 61. Duncan awkwardly makes a “pose.” The Patrons go crazy. Breakdancing Guy helps Duncan up. Everyone claps/cheers, including Owen, and Roddy. Even Caitlin is not immune to moment.

dialogues.speaker: BREAKDANCING GUY
dialogues.text: Nice moves, Pop ‘n Lock. The Beautiful Breakdancer hands Duncan the cardboard. ANGLE ON Owen/Caitlin. He gives her a “See?” look.

dialogues.speaker: CAITLIN
dialogues.text: You got lucky. Owen puts his arm around her waist, but she removes it. ANGLE ON Duncan, carrying the CARDBOARD back over, grinni He’s also DIZZY AS HELL. He can barely walk a straight li In fact, as he tumbles off to the side...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan rides up, barely stopping to hop off of it. He’s t excited. He heads up the stairs, then realizes... He’s st wearing the blue shirt. He pulls it off, and hides it und his T-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan enters, excited. Pam, Trent, Joan, and Kip are the having drinks.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: Hey. Where have you been?

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: PAM
dialogues.text: That’s a long time to be nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: DUNCAN
dialogues.text: Well, that’s where I was. With that, he heads up the STAIRS.  56 57 58 59 62. EXT. WATERPARK - TOP OF DEVIL’S PEAK - DAY 56 Duncan sits at the mouth of the TUBE. Beside him, Roddy, showing him how to run the line. Like Roddy earlier, Dunc is spacing out the SLIDERS. Just then, a BEAUTIFUL TEEN steps up. Duncan instructs her to “hold.” Roddy motions f Duncan to check her out. He complies, staring at her behi but can’t help but blush. Suddenly, a CLEARING OF A THROA ANGLE ON the teen’s MOTHER, glaring.

dialogues.speaker: RODDY
dialogues.text: (mock scolding) Inappropriate, Duncan. Inappropriate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
